before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"2srdk","text":"Prior to sample preparation and DBC analysis, all water samples should be:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":74}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ksu2","text":"Collected and filtered using supplies cleaned according to the above protocol. During sampling, care should be taken to avoid sample contamination (e.g. rinsing sample bottle with sample before collection, collecting water upstream from your position, avoiding the introducing sunscreen/oils from hands to water or inner sample bottle, etc). Samples are typically filtered through pre-cleaned filters with pore sizes ranging from 0.1 to 0.7 μm. Store filtered (un-acidified) water samples in the dark at 4°C until further analysis or up to 48 hours.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"405gi","text":"Analyzed to obtain DOC concentrations. These DOC concentration data are essential for determining volumes for accurate sample preparation and robust DBC quantification. description: {"blocks":[{"key":"f1rgn","text":"Dissolved black carbon (DBC) is the condensed aromatic portion of dissolved organic matter produced from the incomplete combustion of biomass and other thermogenic processes. DBC quantification facilitates the examination of the production, accumulation, cycling, transformation, and effects of biologically recalcitrant condensed aromatic carbon in aquatic environments. Due to the heterogeneous nature of DBC molecules, concentrations are difficult to measure directly. Here, the method for DBC quantification consists of oxidizing condensed aromatic carbon to benzenepolycarboxylic acids (BPCAs), which are used as proxies for the assessment of DBC in the original sample. The concentrations of oxidation products (BPCAs) are quantified using high-performance liquid chromatography. DBC concentrations are determined from the concentration of BPCAs using a previously established conversion factor. Details and full descriptions of the preparative and analytical procedures and techniques of the BPCA method are usually omitted for brevity in published method sections and method-specific papers. With this step-by-step protocol, we aim to clarify the steps of DBC analysis, especially for those adopting or conducting the BPCA method for the first time. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"f8974","text":"A helpful spreadsheet detailing necessary calculations is included here and utilized multiple times throughout the protocol:   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":126}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":125,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6nl1d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adgr9","text":"Expected Protocol Timeline: From start to finish, completion of this protocol for dissolved black carbon (DBC) analysis will take approximately one week. However, there are multiple points in the protocol where the preparative procedures can be paused and resumed at a later time. Before starting each step in the procedure, read ahead to make sure you have allocated sufficient time to complete each step before reaching a designated pause point. To achieve maximum sample preparation efficiency and data consistency, we recommend that samples are prepared in relevant batches, rather than one at a time. For example, solid phase extracted dissolved organic carbon (DOC) can be archived in the freezer until an entire sample set is collected, then the samples can be analyzed for DBC in one steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9gr9h","text":"The solid phase extraction (SPE) cartridges used in this protocol (Agilent Bond Elut PPL cartridge, 1g, 6 mL) is packed with a styrene-divinylbenzene polymer resin that recovers high proportions of dissolved organic matter (DOM) on a per-carbon basis. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"42ds0","text":"Store SPE cartridges in the refrigerator at    until DOM extraction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":44,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"cgm7i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"ck3ld","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"52smh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"8D76CEA08ED311EC802EFB706FB7ACDA","id":"49771","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":39,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2hujo","text":"Do not store cartridges in the freezer as water expansion will cause the caps to come off and resin to dry out.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ff0t8","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2tsb3","text":"Conditioned SPE cartridges may be stored like this in the refrigerator for several weeks to months. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Extraction of DOM
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"b47hj","text":"At this point, the water sample should have been filtered and analyzed for dissolved organic carbon (DOC) concentration. In order to determine the volume of sample necessary to extract, please see the Estimating Sample Volume tab in the Example PPL-BPCA Calculations spreadsheet. In general, approximately 0.5-mg of extracted DOC is used to quantify DBC in the original sample. As extraction efficiencies and amount of DBC present are sample-dependent, we suggest passing more than the minimum volume through the cartridge and instead aim for a volume that will oxidize to ~20uM of benzenehexacarboxylic acid (B6CA). Please see linked spreadsheet and the rest of the protocol for further discussion and elaboration.   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":716,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b8a6v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"akghe","text":"Once the necessary volume is determined, acidify the filtered water sample to pH 2 using hydrochloric acid.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c2t9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ed5qq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17g3l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"24FCB6E0D09C11EC955347E445D5BF8B","id":239123,"original_name":"Example PPL-BPCA Calculations.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hjsvbj36p.xlsx"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fdkdc","text":"Adding 2 mL of 6 N hydrochloric acid (or 1 mL of 12 N hydrochloric acid) to 1 L of filtered sample water usually brings the pH value close to 2. However, depending on sample composition and buffering capacities, additional hydrochloric acid may be needed to sufficiently reduce the pH.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9ea4f","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"anunk","text":"After each hydrochloric acid addition, cap and vigorously mix the sample, then test the pH by dropping the solution onto a pH strip or by using a pH meter.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"29gp1","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":52,"offset":129,"style":"bold"}],"key":"d9utp","text":"The acidification of the sample protonates molecules contained within DOM so they effectively sorb to the conditioned SPE resin. The acidification step is critical for DOM recovery.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Extraction of DOM
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"eqrrr","text":"Place an appropriately sized container beneath the manifold to capture SPE effluent and wait until extraction is complete (i.e. the entire sample volume has passed through the SPE cartridge by gravity).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"clovo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"9iti7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"60m48","text":"Depending upon sample volume, sample composition and/or flow rate, this extraction step can take anywhere from a few hours to a full day to complete. It is typical to set up extractions in the afternoon, then leave the extraction to continue overnight and complete the following steps the following day. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"80vpo","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":34,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"59uep","text":"Possible issues during extraction:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4ritq","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6891d","text":"Small sample bottles - It may be necessary to secure the sample bottles on the shelf, as they may be displaced by the weight of the tubes after sample is drained from the bottle. This is typically a problem for smaller bottle sizes (e.g., less than 1 L) and should be considered during extraction setup.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4kpoa","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2sqit","text":"Bubbles in headspace - Formation of bubbles can introduce air to the resin and slow the flow rate of sample. If small bubbles form in the SPE cartridge headspace, gently tap the side of the cartridge with a pen or similar object. If you observe the formation of large bubbles or major gaps of air in the headspace, remove adapter cap connection and allow sample to flow and refill headspace of cartridge, then reattach adapter. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5i36k","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":19,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"401h","text":"Flocculation of DOM - If there are no bubbles present and flow through SPE cartridge is slow, check to see if the white filter (above resin) has turned brown and/or accumulated sample particulates. In highly concentrated samples (e.g., samples collected from a wetland or during peak river discharge), DOM may flocculate out of solution when acidified to pH 2 and clog the SPE cartridge. If flow is slow, but still dripping, leave samples to extract overnight or for 24 hours. If flow has stopped completely or is prohibitively slow, then you may use another SPE cartridge to extract DOM from the remaining volume. Depending upon sample DOC concentration and expected SPE recovery, the volume of sample extracted prior to clogging may be sufficient for further analyses.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Drying SPE cartridges
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7jn0","text":"Turn on gas flow.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d9ib7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"dj6ve","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2mlgg","text":"Keep gas flow relatively high at first, until water stops spitting rapidly from the SPE cartridges. Here, you want to find a balance that minimizes both drying time and gas waste. This will take some trial and error to determine the appropriate flow rate for your specific drying setup.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6tcp0","text":"In this step, DOM is eluted from the SPE resin with methanol and collected directly in a glass vial. It is important to use analytical grade methanol so as not to contaminate the DOM sample with extraneous material.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":101,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3dm0b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9jvd1","text":"Elute DOM from the SPE resin by adding 3 x 3 mL aliquots of methanol to the cartridge.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"41ave","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"1i2cu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"as9ad","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3u1om","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1eh73","text":"Fill beaker with methanol, then transfer ~3 mL of methanol from beaker to cartridge with a volumetric pipette. Allow methanol to flow through the cartridge until the meniscus is almost touching the white filter located above the resin. Repeat two more times, letting the final 3 mL aliquot of methanol drain completely from the cartridge into the vial.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7jsj4","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"19ee5","text":"The total volume of methanol used to elute DOM from the SPE cartridges described here (Agilent Bond Elut PPL cartridge, 1g, 6 mL) is ~9 mL, but this volume may be adjusted to accommodate different resin masses and/or cartridge headspaces.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cbmn9","text":"At this point, you may continue directly to the next step or store eluate in the freezer until you are ready to continue. This methanol eluate can be stored for years in the freezer as an archive of SPE-DOC for future BPCA analyses. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"de31i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3kcnc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":76,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"8ceoh","text":"Note that each SPE cartridge may be used up to three times before disposal. After DOM elution, SPE cartridges can be rinsed with analytical grade acetone (3 headspace volumes) and set aside to air dry. Once dry, the SPE cartridges can be reconditioned (see steps 1 though 6) and reused for DOM extraction. We recommend that each SPE cartridge is reused with a similar sample type so as to avoid potential cross contamination. For example, do not use an SPE cartridge to first extract a high DOC swamp water sample, then extract a low DOC open ocean sample. It is best when SPE cartridges are reused within the same sample set or for samples collected at the same field site.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

Calculations.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hjswbj36p.xlsx"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":96,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"7gsf4","text":"For robust DBC analysis, we recommend oxidizing ~0.5 mg of solid phase extracted DOC (SPE-DOC). By entering the following values into the spreadsheet, you will calculate the volume of sample passed through the SPE cartridge, the volume of methanol eluate recovered from the SPE cartridge, and the volume of DOM-containing methanol eluate that needs to be dried down for sample oxidation and analysis:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dmqsh","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"h8q9","text":"Sample DOC concentration (μM)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"og85","text":"Mass of full sample bottle (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bm6v6","text":"Mass of empty sample bottle (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8urdl","text":"Mass of empty glass vial (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"14vsg","text":"Mass of full glass vial (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ats0a","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4jul9","text":"Example calculations are included in the spreadsheet.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1te92","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":17,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3arb4","text":"Assumptions made - The calculations used here assume 60% recovery of bulk DOC from river and other freshwater samples and 45% recovery from coastal marine and open ocean samples during solid phase extraction (Dittmar et al., 2008). The percent recovery of SPE-DOC should be adjusted according to the type of water sample being extracted. If you are unsure of what the SPE-DOC recovery is for a specific sample type, you may want to measure it directly. Otherwise, we suggest 50% as a good starting point until you become more familiar with the sample composition.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3gbpg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":40,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2bmpt","text":"What if I have less than 0.5 mg SPE-DOC? Smaller amounts of SPE-DOC may be used for DBC analysis, but this is highly dependent upon the amount and quality of DBC that is expected for a given sample based upon preliminary data or known biogeochemical factors. See Wagner et al. (2017) and the main manuscript text for further discussion on this. When working with a new or biogeochemically unknown sample set, we strongly recommend starting with 0.5 mg SPE-DOC until you become more familiar with the limitations of your analytical setup and sample DBC composition.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Dittmar T, Koch B, Hertkorn N, Kattner G.","can_edit":1,"date":"1213149600","doi":"https://doi.org/10.4319/lom.2008.6.230","guid":"9E3188608ED411EC802EFB706FB7ACDA","id":1560,"journal":"Limnol. Paper or adhesive labels may burn or be removed in the oxidation oven.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Transfer of SPE-DOC eluate to ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3dhc9","text":"Using a mechanical pipette, fitted with a glass Pasteur pipette tip, quantitatively transfer the calculated volume of methanol eluate (\"V MeOH to dry\" in spreadsheet) to the corresponding ampule. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9o3gt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"87k6i","text":"Triple-rinse the glass pipette tip with fresh methanol before use and between each sample to prevent cross contamination. Dispose of each rinsing to the appropriate solvent waste container.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9ei4j","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"cdav8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":24,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"30b22","text":"Mechanical pipette setup - Here, we use a small piece of silicone tubing to fit the glass Pasteur pipette tip to the mechanical pipette. Using the glass pipette prevents possible contamination of organic material from plastic pipette tips.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7sul7","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":31,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"fad83","text":"Quantitative transfer technique - When transferring the methanol eluate, insert tip of Pasteur pipette into methanol eluate and slowly pump up and down 3 to 5 times until the headspace in the Pasteur pipette is equilibrated and bubbles are no longer emitted from the pipette tip. After equilibrating, draw in the target amount of methanol eluate and transfer to the ampule. When transferring, place the pipette tip all the way down the neck of the ampule and try to make sure the eluate is deposited directly to the bottom of the ampule. Gently pump the pipette 3 to 5 times to ensure the total volume of methanol eluate is expelled into the ampule.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e9d04","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":56,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"ec2cb","text":"What if the \"V MeOH to dry\" volume is greater than 2 mL? Each ampule can contain up to 2 mL of methanol eluate. If the volume of eluate that needs to be dried down exceeds 2 mL, then we suggest transferring and drying the eluate in aliquots of 2 mL or less (see next step). Do not overfill the ampules, as this will cause the SPE-DOC to dry on the neck of the ampule and may interfere with analysis later.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Evaporation of methanol from SPE-DOC eluate
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"786qh","text":"In this step methanol is evaporated completely from the eluate to obtain the dry SPE-DOC residue for oxidation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4t7f7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a73jn","text":"Place ampules in a properly vented drying oven set to   . Loosely place a Kimwipe over the ampule openings to prevent contamination from extraneous material during drying. Depending upon the eluate volume, methanol evaporation can take anywhere from 12 to 36 hours. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":54,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"9sg6u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"eouqm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9uge0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f1iij","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f9soo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"96D0E9408ED311EC802EFB706FB7ACDA","id":"49772","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"60","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":170,"offset":131,"style":"bold"}],"key":"ak3po","text":"If you are unsure whether methanol is completely evaporated, then place the ampules back in the oven and dry for a few more hours. The reaction between concentrated nitric acid and excess methanol is explosive, therefore complete evaporation of methanol before moving on to the next step is essential.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5cu3u","text":"Do not begin this step if you do not have the time to flame-seal ampules and perform sample oxidation immediately thereafter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":125}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aokh9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"73kgo","text":"Using a volumetric, mechanical pipette, add 0.5 mL of analytical grade nitric acid (15.8N) to each ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7d2f4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"u819","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bm4n5","text":"During nitric acid addition, visually examine the ampules to determine whether there is any SPE-DOC residue in the ampule neck. If there is any visible SPE-DOC in the neck (methanol eluate can creep up the sides of the ampule during drying and deposit SPE-DOC), rinse it down with nitric acid.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3slij","text":"Flame seal the glass ampules.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ees0p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"17nnj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":101,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":87,"offset":309,"style":"bold"}],"key":"73vmr","text":"If you are new to sealing glass ampules with an open flame torch, practice first with empty ampules. Do not attempt to seal ampules containing critical samples until you are comfortable and confident with the flame sealing technique. Inadequate sealing of samples will result in sample loss during oxidation. Please see the online version of this protocol for a video of ampule-sealing technique.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2q3t2","text":"The flame sealing of ampules requires a beaker of water, long metal forceps, safety glasses, and a blow torch that is sufficiently hot enough to melt borosilicate glass.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"827s2","text":"Turn on the torch. Hold ampule at a 45 degree angle. Use your hand to stabilize the base of the ampule and the forceps to stabilize the neck of the ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"nrrl","text":"Hold the upper neck area of the ampule in the flame and slowly rotate until the glass begins to soften. Once the glass is sufficiently malleable, gently rotate and pull apart the top and bottom portions of the ampule by pulling the forceps further away from the flame until the top portion is removed and the neck of the ampule is pinched closed. After removing the top part of the ampule, hold the sealed portion in the flame for an extra second or so to ensure a good seal.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bubm1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"46dg7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"di50","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"fl8v3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"video","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"12339A406F1911ECA6296F943B28F2BB","height":0,"id":197355,"is_video":true,"legend":"","mime":"video/mp4","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"seal.mp4","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gaznbj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gazmbj36p.mp4","width":0}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7vqun","text":"Do not twist the glass too quickly, or before the glass is sufficiently malleable, as this may result in a poor seal. Rotate the bottom of the ampule with your hand and gently open and close the forceps to obtain the best seal.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"624tl","text":"Place the top piece of the ampule (pulled off using forceps) into the beaker of water to cool. Carefully place sealed ampule into a tray using the forceps.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d2sml","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"c1afs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":31,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"a7nko","text":"Freshly sealed ampules are HOT - Move them using the forceps until they are cool to the touch.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1a07b","text":"Examine the ampule for a proper seal and repeat the previous step for each ampule in the sample set.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"46g82","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bbo8t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"8k9ck","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6l671","text":"The sealed end of the ampule should resemble a candle flame. If you notice any holes in the seal, you may attempt to reseal using the same method described above. Note that it is more difficult to seal an ampule on the second try because the neck area is considerably shorter. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Oxidation of SPE-DOC with nitric acid
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cngpp","text":"Wrap ampules in aluminum foil pouches, usually 3 to 5 ampules per pouch.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c66n3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"7sjmv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dnbuk","text":"While not completely necessary, wrapping ampules in foil helps organize large numbers of ampules during oxidation. In the event of an ampule leak or breakage, wrapping ampules can maintain the integrity and readability of ampule labels. If you are unsure whether a particular ampule has a strong seal, you may want to wrap that ampule individually. If analyzing replicates, you may choose to wrap replicate ampules together.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Oxidation of SPE-DOC with nitric acid
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ccq13","text":"Place pouches together in a glass beaker or other glass container and place in a temperature controlled oven.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a96lt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"8d5m1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2ilhg","text":"This step is optional, but it makes it easier to transfer ampules in and out of the oven safely and efficiently. steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"97hp2","text":"Remove steel needle covers and clean each needle with a Kimwipe soaked in methanol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7at3c","text":"Insert needle into the headspace of the ampule so the tip of the needle is hovering just above the surface of the nitric acid in the ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"amstt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"5de5h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":69,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2ck8t","text":"Take care when inserting and removing needles to and from the ampules - There is a risk getting sand in your samples. If you accidentally introduce sand to the ampules, take notes on which samples were affected and check BPCA analyses later for possible signs of contamination. Since the BPCAs are chromatographically separated, contamination from sand is unlikely to interfere with DBC quantification results.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3e17s","text":"SLOWLY increase gas flow. The nitric acid solution in each ampule should shimmer slightly, not sputter aggressively. You may observe dark orange-to-light colored fumes emitting from the ampules.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4krff","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"d6a97","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fog84","text":"To optimize evaporation, you may adjust gas flow and/or needle height periodically during dry down as the liquid level decreases. This step requires a watchful eye and some degree of “babysitting” to ensure efficient evaporation. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"64gsf","text":"After nitric acid has completely evaporated, turn off gas flow and remove needles from ampules and remove ampules from the sand bath. Gently wipe down the exterior of each ampule to remove excess sand.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5b783","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"4s8hq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":48,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"basa2","text":"Signs that nitric acid is completely evaporated - If the steel needle and area around the opening of the ampule are completely dry, then it is likely that all nitric acid has been evaporated. If you remove the ampule and notice that some nitric acid remains, simply replace the ampule in the sand bath and continue drying. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7481s","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":37,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9n0b5","text":"Appearance of BPCA-containing residue - The dry BPCA-containing residue left in the ampule is typically clear, white, or light yellow in color. The residue may not always be readily apparent to the naked eye.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"avt80","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":41,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bbv1n","text":"Turn off gas flow BEFORE removing needles - If you remove needles while gas is still flowing, then sand will blow all over the place.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"bmki","text":"Repeat previous step until all samples are dried down. Wipe down needles with a Kimwipe soaked in methanol between each batch of samples added to sand bath to prevent cross contamination.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Transfer of BPCAs from ampules to HPLC vials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8oq25","text":"In this section, the BPCA-containing residue in the ampule is re-dissolved in mobile phase and transferred to the HPLC vial for analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ccfeq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eo9nd","text":"Label HPLC vials with sample identifier or name, then add inserts to reduce interior volume. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eq3tb","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"54tj6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7h8bh","text":"Note that vial inserts may not be needed if mobile phase volume is sufficiently high (e.g., \u003e0.5 mL). steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Transfer of BPCAs from ampules to HPLC vials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cqqpa","text":"Transfer the target volume of mobile phase A to the ampule containing the dry BPCA-containing residue using a volumetric pipette. Record the volume of mobile phase A added to the ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":130,"length":56}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3mnvh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"4jlhk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5em6i","text":"Mobile phase A is a dilute phosphoric acid solution (0.6 M; pH 1). See step 51 for additional details on formulation of HPLC mobile phases associated with this protocol.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"908kn","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dg831","text":"If 0.5 mg of sample SPE-DOC is oxidized (see step 28), we typically recommend re-dissolving the BPCA-containing residue in 200 μL of mobile phase A for robust BPCA detection. steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Transfer of BPCAs from ampules to HPLC vials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cpd4n","text":"Rinse the entire interior surface of the ampule with the volume of mobile phase A added.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"epiqt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"cujad","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ancq6","text":"This step usually requires a combination of gentle shaking, rolling, and tilting of the ampule for a minute or two to effectively re-dissolve the BPCAs in the mobile phase A added. It is important to make sure that the mobile phase rinses every part of the interior surface of the ampule to ensure quantitative detection and analysis of BPCAs in a given sample. Whatever method you use to re-dissolve the BPCAs, keep your approach consistent among different samples. Take care not to spill any mobile phase during this step.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Transfer of BPCAs from ampules to HPLC vials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c7473","text":"Using a clean glass or plastic pipette, transfer the mobile phase in the ampule, which now contains re-dissolved BPCAs, from the ampule to the insert in the corresponding HPLC vial.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ao8pr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"a26sn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7uhao","text":"When transferring the sample, place the pipette tip at the bottom of the vial insert and slowly deposit the sample to avoid bubble formation at the bottom of the insert.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1q23u","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d0u8q","text":"Note that there may still be some mobile phase residue left in the ampule after transfer to the HPLC vial. This will not affect the accurate calculation of DBC concentrations because the concentration of BPCAs in the vial insert is representative of all BPCAs derived from the sample dissolved in the target volume of mobile phase A originally added to the ampule.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Transfer of BPCAs from ampules to HPLC vials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c995c","text":"Cap the HPLC vials. steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Chromatographic separation of individual BPCAs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4t4uc","text":"The HPLC separation method described here was first presented by Wagner et al. (2017) for online compound-specific stable carbon isotopic analysis. In this protocol, we use the same chromatographic parameters, but with UV detection, for the efficient quantification of DBC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9or0c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9fb3n","text":"HPLC system and user-related assumptions - For the purposes of this protocol, we assume that the user will have access to an HPLC system that is equipped with an autosampler, binary or quaternary pump (for gradient separation), a UV or photo diode array detector, and software to assemble methods and sequences and for instrumental operation. We also assume that the user has basic knowledge of how to operate an HPLC system and/or has access to someone who can assist them with basic operation of an HPLC system. For example, we do not go into detail about how to flush solvent lines or properly hook up and equilibrate an HPLC column. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b8rrp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"960ds","text":"HPLC instrument settings for the chromatographic separation of BPCAs are as follows: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":85}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fok66","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3938s","text":"Column: Agilent Poroshell 120 phenyl-hexyl column (4.6 x 150 mm, 2.7 μm) with corresponding guard column (4.6 x 5 mm, 2.7 μm)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"15tcp","text":"Mobile phase A: Phosphoric acid (0.6 M; pH 1)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3e0ft","text":"Mobile phase B: Sodium phosphate buffer (20 mM; pH 6)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f4qqs","text":"Flow rate: 500 μL min-1","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":21,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5usi7","text":"Column temperature: 25°C (if available)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"11pm2","text":"Autosampler temperature: 25°C (if available)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4hi7l","text":"Injection volume: 25 μL","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5v6f6","text":"Peak detection: 240 nm","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cnkt2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8j1jb","text":"Set up the HPLC according to the parameters listed above.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Chromatographic separation of individual BPCAs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dn2rn","text":"Place blank, BPCA standard, and sample vials into the appropriate autosampler positions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtr7f","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8uptj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1347n","text":"If you are analyzing samples that were previously stored in the freezer, shake the vial downward in a flicking motion to ensure the liquid in the vial settles to the bottom of the insert and the solution is re-mixed. This ensures that there is not a concentration gradient nor bubbles in the vial due to freezing/thawing. You may also use a pipette to mix and deposit your sample, but this may introduce extraneous material to the vial.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Chromatographic separation of individual BPCAs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fdqmg","text":"At this point, the HPLC system should be set up for BPCA analysis and the column is properly equilibrated with mobile phase (70% A and 30% B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b58ab","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bl6o","text":"Run the HPLC sequence.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bg1eh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"4ccrm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4jopj","text":"Note that the mobile phase B reservoir will empty faster than the mobile phase A reservoir. Depending upon the length of the sequence, it could take several days to analyze a full sample set. We suggest checking on the instrument at least daily to refill mobile phase reservoirs and to check for leaks or other observable issues with separation. We also suggest checking whether the BPCA standards ran well before continuing to analyze the rest of the dataset.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
